text: hey trent. Thanks so much for cranking this out. Think there’s a lot to like here. The way the details expand seems really nice. I think this is a really good study because it highlights the complexity of all of the stuff in play. For me, I think it could be worth experimenting with a version that has a little less overall movement. Maybe we leverage more fade-out / fade-in, instead sliding something across the screen. While I enjoy some of the playfulness I see here — the sleep icon bouncing in, and pushing the container down — I wonder if it fits with our theme of daring simplicity. Any other thoughts?
<@U02AUNA0P>, <@U0XCJ372R>, <@U0MKH0BE0>: would be cool to get your thoughts on these motion studies as well

yeah, so there’s a few things there. first off, i think a lot of this will be stripped out for 1.0 (that’s mostly assumed at this point though i guess). i think a fade out/fade in could be a nice way to reduce movement on the Add button. Re: playfulness on the sleep icon… i think we should discuss objectives on adding new icons. two pieces of client feedback that i’m woking with are Christian’s request for more “fun and playfulness” that we talked about including through motion, the other being Scott’s comments about how they want adding a new activity to be “an exciting moment” (paraphrasing here). the jump up and dip down makes it much more noticeable than a fade in would be, and it has the added benefit of hinting at the summary drawer that users will find details on that activity. it’s a first pass, so i’m definitely open to other ideas on how we want to portray these new activity events
I like the motion of the icon coming in, but I’m not sold in the dipping down part. I feel like the playful bounce upwards is more than enough.

all - i’ve been catching up on this thread. One thing I honestly don’t know the answer to is how any of our motion connects to one another, even in something as abstract as tone (e.g. playful). 

In this particular case, do we have precedent anywhere else in app motion to help inform how we make this specific implementation?

And building on melissa’s last point — I think that this motion serves a few different needs: Hinting, understanding that something happened, tone, to a certain extent voice of the ‘motion’, etc. 

Wondering if any of those aspects could help inform an answer here. 

From my perspective, after looking at the latest piece a few times, I think it could go a few different ways. One immediate thought is that the icon animating in alongside the drawer pull down is sort of two beats (icon = 1, drawer = 2). As I look at it, assuming we do a drawer thing, I feel like it could be a more singular motion. 

But that last part is peanut gallery jerk ewald thoughts. Take with however many grains of salt make sense.

let’s see... 

for hinting at the drawer, curious to hear other ideas that are being imagined or if it’s just not what we see here so far. we agree it’s necessary to show how to use the system. instead of showing the actual drawing peeking through, should we have a new element suggest the existence of the drawer? a dropdown arrow to the far right? 

one of the challenges we’re up against, like melissa said, is how many interactions we have packed on this page. my current understanding is we are using pull down and/or pinch to get to week view. if this is so, previous talk about hinting the summary drawer with scrolling would contradict affordances. are we saying the summary drawer opens when you touch _anywhere_ on that bar? or does tapping an icon take you to full detail screen where tapping any open spot reveals the drawer?

i think it would be a useful exercise if we pinned down a clean assignment of gestures and outcomes for all the things the screen needs to do.


regarding tone, this is a tricky thing. it’s proving to be a challenge to retroactively figure that out so late in the game. the only existing example we have of motion in the app so far is the home pattern multiplying, which is something, but not a lot to model motion with for all other instances. i’m still trying to figure out the appropriate direction for motion so these convos are helping me get there. as far as playfulness goes, i distinctly remember that coming up multiple times, as recently as the last time we presented work to Christian, and to melissa’s point i think it’s something that fits well with who we’ve understood Sara to be. and yes, the extent of playfulness is still up for debate. but i struggle to think of how something can be daringly simple and celebratory simultaneously. most other instances of motion are heavily dependent on fades (the least abrasive type of transitions). i’m wondering how we can move outside of that when needed while still adhering to our visual tone (genuinely looking for input here). 

i think with motion across the entire app, <@U0265G76F>, there’s a couple of opportunities for motion but really not a lot. the home screen is where all the magic happens. the experience outside the home screen is relatively straight forward, with a couple opportunities for stuff on Dx instances.

the other challenge is that non-standard motion has been categorically denied by the client and considered out of scope for v1.0 except for the pattern (planning on fighting that a bit on monday), that’s another deal though.
